title: LDAP login possible even though account doesn't match user filter

profile.name: Nextcloud
profile.about: Access, share and protect your files, calendars, contacts, communication & more at home and in your enterprise.

vulnerability_information:
We have set up a ldap user filter to match only those users in our ldap directory which should get access to nextcloud. User count shows correct number of users as expected and the filter correctly shows only the users we want in an ldapsearch.

The ldap directory contains a lot of other accounts which don't match that filter and which should not get access to nextcloud. However, now we found out that it is possible for any valid user account in the ldap directory to log into nextcloud. The account is set up and login is successful even through the account does not match the filter.

The account won't be listed on the Users page of an nextcloud admin user, thus from that view the account doesn't exist.

I have just tested it with 11.0.1 (centos7, installed from rpms) and I was able to log in with a test account which does not match the user filter...

activities.message:
The login filter accepts everyone with a uid: ``(uid=%uid)``

Most commonly you would like to have this AND-combined with the value from the user filter, resulting in:  ``(&(&(objectclass=posixAccount)(!(nsAccountLock=true))(|(o=███-mitarbeiter)(o=█████-uni)))(uid=%uid))``

activities.message:
No. This is absolutely not what I want. I do not want to duplicate the user list filter into the login attributes. That's totally misleading. The LDAP Users configuration page says: "Nextcloud access is limited to users meeting these criteria". That's what I expect from that configuration. That's how all other LDAP client software I have configured in the past does.

You configure the userlist filter. You check the count and it shows the correct count. After configuration you check the Users page and you see all users listed which match the userlist filter. But you nowhere see any of those other users which have been able to log in. Basically they are hidden from view although they can access the nextcloud server.

Requiring the admin to duplicate the filter into the login attributes is simply wrong and just causes serious security issues. We just accidentally noticed that other users where able to access the server. I guess there are many other installations out there which have the exact problem and won't notice until you look very carefully which account directories have been created on the server. Also, remember that duplicating the exact filter is erroneous. You must always remember and make sure that both filters are in sync. Seriously?

I think it's mandatory that the user filter does exactly what it says: "Nextcloud access is limited to users meeting these criteria". And the login attributes page should just create the link between the login name entered by the user to the LDAP user entry.

That's also the way how you are lead during initial configuration: you set up the user filter first, check the user count, find it O.K. and thus expect for the next steps that this filter is active and used everywhere for user access.

Thus I can only ask you to please fix this. This is a security issues. And please not by adding remarks on the configuration page but by applying the userlist filter at all places where user accounts are accessed. Can't be too hard to do as you only have to AND the login "filter" with the userlist filter at all occurrences of the login "filter". It's very different from what every other ldap software I use does. I am pretty sure that there are many other installations out there which have the same problem and won't even notice it...

activities.message:
Thank you for your reply @gvde!

> The LDAP Users configuration page says: "Nextcloud access is limited to users meeting these criteria". That's what I expect from that configuration. That's how all other LDAP client software I have configured in the past does.

Yes, this wording is totally wrong. It should be clear [within the documentation](https://docs.nextcloud.com/server/11/admin_manual/configuration_user/user_auth_ldap.html#users-tab), but that obviously does not help, when not looking intentionally for it. 

> You configure the userlist filter. You check the count and it shows the correct count. After configuration you check the Users page and you see all users listed which match the userlist filter. But you nowhere see any of those other users which have been able to log in. Basically they are hidden from view although they can access the nextcloud server.

Exactly, this is what is possible to achieve. In a corner use case to have hidden users, when configured deliberately. Also the possibility it enables a way to lock out users from this specific service when enriched with an attribute while keeping all its shares to other users in tact.

Frankly, I would be happier to have both filters united, and only login attributes specified. Due to the cases specified above the separation is kept, however.

On another note, when not manually configuring the filter, the wizard by default uses the user filter and connects the selected attributes accordingly. And also when configuring the filter the user filter is taken over to ease the configuration.

> Thus I can only ask you to please fix this. This is a security issues. And please not by adding remarks on the configuration page but by applying the userlist filter at all places where user accounts are accessed. Can't be too hard to do as you only have to AND the login "filter" with the userlist filter at all occurrences of the login "filter". It's very different from what every other ldap software I use does. I am pretty sure that there are many other installations out there which have the same problem and won't even notice it...

Again, so far this way of configuration is providing greater flexibility towards the administrator and depending on the specific use case the proposed change can indeed be breaking.

Nevertheless, we will take your arguments into consideration and look into improving the user experience in of the next major releases, most likely Nextcloud 13. Until, we will fix the misleading wording. As such we do not see this as a security issue given our [threat model](https://nextcloud.com/security/threat-model/).

activities.message:
> Exactly, this is what is possible to achieve. In a corner use case to have hidden users, when configured deliberately. Also the possibility it enables a way to lock out users from this specific service when enriched with an attribute while keeping all its shares to other users in tact.

Well, if that's what you want I would rather go the opposite direction: enter two filters to clearly distinguish between "public" and "hidden" entries but keep the login attribute filter for the purpose of mapping the username entered by the user to the ldap entries.

For a standard setup the Users tab would be the userlist filter for all users allowed to log into the server.

The login attribute tab is the mapping which will be added to the userlist filter when used. Do it as a filter as it is now (with the filter always ANDed to the userlist filter) or set it up as simple list of attribute names to be used to find the username.

The hidden user feature should be advanced or expert setting only. Here you could define an additional filter based on which entries are hidden. This way the hidden list is always a subset of the full userlist.

Of course, the hidden entries should never be hidden from an administrative account, i.e. all accounts should be visible on the Users page of an admin. Right now, not even the admin sees those "hidden" account thus you can't set a quota or assign them to a group...

In the same manner you could also have an additional advanced/expert configuration for locked out accounts. Many ldap servers already have some attribute for this purpose (e.g. nsAccountLock, which will probably prevent a successful bind to this entry anyway). Thus with this additional lockout filter you can define which of all existing userlist entries should not be able to log in.

This way you  have a simple and clear setup for most standard cases (user filter and the login map filter). For advanced use it's possible to hide and lock out some entries based on any additional filters. I'd say this way it's pretty hard to set it up incorrectly...

activities.message:
What makes those "hidden" accounts either more "dangerous": you don't see them anywhere, you cannot delete them. We are trying to determine which accounts have been created due to this "glitch" and it seems there is no easy way.  occ user:report only shows the number of accounts matching the userlist filter.  user:list does not show the other account. ldap:show-remnants doesn't show it either, even when we add the userlist filter to the login filter.

There is no way to delete them. occ user:delete says the user does not exist.

So basically, it seems as if those accounts don't appear anywhere and it's impossible to delete them through web interface or occ cli... The accounts are not only "hidden" but kind of "stealthed" as they are even invisible to all admin access...
